key_points: Digital twins are valuable for modeling, visualizing, and simulating complex systems.
The work focuses on the challenges of real-time visualization of a digital twin of the Frontier supercomputer.
Augmented reality is explored as a primary interface for interacting with and extracting information from the digital twin.
The goal is to combine telemetry with simulation for a holistic understanding of HPC systems.
The prototype uses Unreal Engine 5 and has over 150,000 actors.
Challenges include large scale, big data, and visualization performance.
A digital twin is an evolving digital representation of a physical object or process.
Simulations for digital twins are often run on HPC systems.
Modeling HPC systems *with* digital twins is a relatively new area.
Digital twins promise a holistic understanding of HPC systems by combining telemetry and simulation.
Visualization is crucial for human interaction with a digital twin.
The work aims to improve overall system efficiency through digital twin insights.
The Oak Ridge Leadership Computing Facility (OLCF) installed the Frontier supercomputer, achieving 1.1 ExaFlops.
Frontier consists of 9,472 compute nodes with 9,472 CPUs and 37,888 GPUs.
The system is comprised of seven rows of HPE Cray EX cabinets, each supported by Cooling Distribution Units (CDUs).
Each compute cabinet contains eight chassis, each with eight blades and two compute nodes.
Nodes contain one AMD EPYC CPU and four AMD Instinct GPUs.
The system generates one million data points each second.
The goal is to allow users and system engineers to interact with the virtual representation of the system and understand its behavior.
The prototype was re-implemented in Unreal Engine 5 (UE5) for AR/VR capabilities.
The system hierarchy is built using UE5 blueprints, mirroring the physical system layout.
The current prototype has over 150,000 UE5 actors.
Data is represented by changing material colors based on telemetry values.
Telemetry data is queried from a service and distributed to relevant actors.
Thermo-fluid simulations are integrated using the Functional Mock-up Interface (FMI).
The system's extreme scale (components, data, and domain interactions) presents a significant challenge.
The volume, velocity, variety, and veracity of telemetry data are major concerns.
Visualizing a large number of actors (over 150,000) impacts performance, especially in AR.
Balancing detail and performance is crucial for interactive visualization.
Combining telemetry and simulation in the same 3D scene enables unique capabilities.
Spatial and temporal correlation of information provides a deeper understanding of system behavior.
Adaptive layout of information is needed to avoid information overload.
Interactive Level of Detail (LoD) can improve performance and focus.
Integrating AR with web-based dashboards can bridge the gap between data analysis and spatial context.
The digital twin can be used for facility design, operations, and what-if scenario analysis.
